dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Valentina Volkodav—marching from the Volga to Berlin at just 19. Can you even imagine that journey?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Valentina Volkodav-marching from the Volga to Berlin at just nineteen. Can you even imagine that journey?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Valentina Arkhipovna joined the frontlines at the age of 19. She marched from the Volga to Berlin.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And she did it all the way to the end, um, spending Victory Day in Berlin itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And she did it all the way to the end, um, spending Victory Day in Berlin itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: She spent Victory Day, May 9, 1945, in Berlin.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—she was part of a bridge-building unit under enemy fire. Building crossings while being shot at.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-she was part of a bridge-building unit under enemy fire. Building crossings while being shot at.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: She served in the 41st military bridge-building mechanized unit from October 1, 1941, to October 20, 1945, first as a filing clerk and later as an accountant in the financial settlement group. Throughout those years, her military unit worked on the frontlines of the Belarusian and Ukrainian fronts under enemy fire, building bridges and providing crossings for advancing troops.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and she met her husband Yakov in that same unit. They married after the war, which is just… incredible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and she met her husband Yakov in that same unit. They married after the war, which is just... incredible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Valentina Arkhipovna met her future husband, Yakov, during the war in the same unit. After the victory over Japan, they married in Irkutsk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then she lived to 103! She just celebrated that birthday in March, with a military band outside her window.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then she lived to one hundred three! She just celebrated that birthday in March, with a military band outside her window.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This year, she celebrated her 103rd birthday, inspiring everyone around her with her spirit. A military band performed under her window in honor of the veteran.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I love what she said about living with joy—"I'm in love with life." After everything she saw and endured.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I love what she said about living with joy-I'm in love with life. After everything she saw and endured.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: "I live with a smile and joy. I'm in love with life. Enjoy life! I wish everyone to live to 100 like I did. It's such a blessing to live!" Valentina Arkhipovna said at the time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. To go through all that and still be so positive… it's really something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. To go through all that and still be so positive... it's really something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And she was an accountant later on, right? At a ceramics factory. Talk about a shift from building bridges at the front.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And she was an accountant later on, right? At a ceramics factory. Talk about a shift from building bridges at the front.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until retirement, she worked as an accountant at a ceramics factory in Tselinograd.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, from the frontlines to finance. But she never lost that spirit. Even last year, she wanted to lay flowers at the Eternal Flame.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, from the frontlines to finance. But she never lost that spirit. Even last year, she wanted to lay flowers at the Eternal Flame.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In May 2023, Valentina Volkodav expressed a desire to lay flowers at the Eternal Flame to pay tribute to all those who died in the war and the veterans who have passed away in peacetime.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They made it happen for her too. The whole city came out to honor her. That's beautiful.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They made it happen for her too. The whole city came out to honor her. That's beautiful.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That tribute was organized by the city's veterans' council at the request of her and her family. It turned into a heartfelt celebration. Many people gathered at the Eternal Flame, with passersby stopping to congratulate and thank the veteran.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Now there are only two World War II veterans left in her whole region. Makes you realize how important these stories are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Now there are only two World War I I veterans left in her whole region. Makes you realize how important these stories are.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to official data, only two WWII veterans remain in the North Kazakhstan region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. We can't forget people like her—the ones who marched across continents and still found joy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. We can't forget people like her-the ones who marched across continents and still found joy.
